title: MA Personal Lines Remediation Exam 2
description: A 25-question practice exam targeting critical weaknesses in General Insurance and Regulation, plus P&C Basics and Other Coverages, avoiding topics covered in previous uploaded exams.

questions.question: Which characteristic of an insurance contract states that the insured must perform a specific act (pay premiums) in exchange for the insurer's promise to pay claims, making it a 'promise in exchange for an act'?
questions.explanation: A unilateral contract is described as an 'act in exchange for a promise' or a 'promise in exchange for an act already performed.' Only one party (the insurer) makes a legally enforceable promise.
questions.distractor_logic: Aleatory refers to unequal value exchange. Conditional means the contract requires specific conditions to be met. Personal means it covers the person, not the property.

questions.question: If a producer violates a Cease and Desist order issued by the Commissioner, they may be subject to a fine of up to:
questions.explanation: Anyone who violates a cease and desist order may be fined up to $10,000 per violation and be subject to license suspension or revocation.
questions.distractor_logic: $1,000 is the fine for general unfair practices or failing to appear. $500 is for unlicensed compensation. $25,000 is not a standard fine limit in this section.

questions.question: When an insured cancels a property insurance policy during the policy period, the return premium is calculated on what basis?
questions.explanation: Property and liability contracts involve two basic cancellation concepts: short rate when an insured cancels the policy, and pro rata when the insurer cancels.
questions.distractor_logic: Pro rata applies when the *insurer* cancels. Flat rate implies the policy was never in force.

questions.question: The Fair Credit Reporting Act of 1970 allows an insurer to conduct consumer reports. If a consumer questions the accuracy of the report, they have the right to:

options.B: Request a copy of the report from the insurer.
options.C: Request a copy of the report from the reporting agency and demand correction.
options.D: Demand the insurer reveal the source of all underwriting data.

questions.explanation: The applicant has a right to request a copy of the report from the *provider* (the reporting agency), not the insurer. If information is incorrect, they may request it be corrected.
questions.distractor_logic: The law does not require the insurer to send the copy; the consumer must go to the agency. Suing is not the immediate remedy provided by the Act.

questions.question: In Massachusetts, an insurer must file a notice of appointment with the Commissioner within how many days of executing an agency contract?
questions.explanation: To appoint a producer as its agent, the appointing insurer shall file a notice of appointment within 15 days from the date the agency contract is executed.
questions.distractor_logic: 30 days is the timeframe for notifying the Commissioner of *termination*. 10 and 45 days are incorrect for appointments.

questions.question: Under the National Flood Insurance Program, the standard 30-day waiting period for coverage to take effect may be waived if:

options.A: The applicant pays the premium in full immediately.
options.B: The property is located in an Emergency Program community.
options.C: The policy is written in conjunction with a mortgage loan closing.
options.D: The applicant has previously had flood insurance.

questions.explanation: The waiting period may be waived if a new policy is being written in conjunction with a mortgage loan.
questions.distractor_logic: Payment of premium starts the clock but does not waive the wait. Program status and prior insurance do not automatically waive the statutory waiting period.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a 'Physical Hazard'?

options.B: Leaving keys in an unlocked car

questions.explanation: Physical hazards are physical items or conditions that increase the chance of loss, such as storing gasoline in a garage, faulty wiring, or a pothole.
questions.distractor_logic: A is Moral hazard (dishonesty). B and D are Morale hazards (carelessness/attitude).

questions.question: Producers and adjusters are required to maintain records of any written complaints received for a period of:
questions.explanation: Producers and adjusters must maintain any complaints received for a period of two years with a record of their disposition.
questions.distractor_logic: 3 years is the license renewal period. 5 years is the domestic insurer exam frequency. 1 year is incorrect.

questions.question: In liability insurance, the term 'Robbery' is best distinguished from 'Burglary' by which characteristic?

options.B: A person-to-person encounter or threat of violence

questions.explanation: Robbery involves a person-to-person encounter between the robber and victim or a physical threat. Burglary requires visible signs of forcible entry but generally no person-to-person encounter.
questions.distractor_logic: A describes Burglary. C is incorrect (robbery can involve any property). D is Embezzlement or Larceny.

questions.question: Which of the following persons would be EXEMPT from the continuing education requirements in Massachusetts?

options.A: A producer licensed for less than 1 year
options.B: A nonresident producer who has satisfied CE requirements in their home state
options.C: A producer selling only auto insurance

questions.explanation: An individual who holds a nonresident license in this State is exempt from the C.E. requirement if they are subject to a C.E. requirement in their home State.
questions.distractor_logic: New resident producers must still complete CE. Auto producers are not exempt. Business entities are licensed differently, but the individuals within them must comply.

questions.question: Which type of liability limit applies to the total amount of losses occurring during the entire policy period, rather than per accident?
questions.explanation: Aggregate limits provide a maximum limit of liability for the total amount of losses occurring during the policy period. Every claim paid reduces this limit.
questions.distractor_logic: Split and Combined Single limits generally apply per accident. Per Occurrence limits reinstate after each loss.

questions.question: To qualify for a Personal Umbrella Policy, insurers generally require the insured to maintain underlying liability coverage for all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Underlying policies for a personal umbrella include personal auto, homeowners, comprehensive personal liability, and watercraft liability. Professional liability is a commercial exposure.
questions.distractor_logic: A, B, and D are standard underlying personal requirements.

questions.question: If an insurer terminates a producer's appointment, they must notify the Commissioner within:
questions.explanation: An insurer that terminates the appointment, employment, or contract with a producer shall notify the Commissioner within 30 days following the effective date of termination.
questions.distractor_logic: 15 days is for the *initial* appointment notice. 10 and 60 days are incorrect.

questions.question: The 'Loss Ratio' of an insurer is calculated by dividing:
questions.explanation: A loss ratio is determined by dividing the losses an insurer incurs during the year by the amount of earned premiums collected.
questions.distractor_logic: A describes the Expense Ratio. C and D are incorrect calculations.

questions.question: Absolute or Strict Liability is often imposed on owners of wild animals or explosives because:

options.C: Liability is imposed without regard to fault.

questions.explanation: Strict (or absolute) liability is imposed without regard to fault... applicable to hazardous activities like owning dangerous animals or explosives.
questions.distractor_logic: Negligence does not need to be proven (B). The risk is insurable (A). Damages are compensatory, not necessarily punitive (D).

questions.question: Making false or untrue statements regarding a competing insurer's financial condition is defined as:
questions.explanation: No person may make false or untrue statements regarding a competing insurer. Any such comments or remarks will be deemed to be defamation.
questions.distractor_logic: Twisting involves policy replacement. Rebating is offering inducements. Coercion is restraint of trade.

questions.question: To be eligible for the Massachusetts FAIR Plan, a property generally must:

options.A: Be located in a rural area.
options.B: Be vacant for more than 60 days.

questions.explanation: The FAIR Plan must inspect the property to be covered before coverage will be provided. It will not provide coverage for vacant or structurally inferior buildings.
questions.distractor_logic: A is incorrect (FAIR Plan is often for urban areas). B is incorrect (vacant properties are ineligible). D is incorrect (covers personal and commercial).

questions.question: A person who falsifies information in a sworn statement (such as a claim form) to collect benefits may be guilty of:
questions.explanation: If a person falsifies information in a sworn statement (i.e., claim form)... he or she may be guilty of perjury. The penalty is a fine of $100-$1,000 or up to 1 year prison.
questions.distractor_logic: Larceny typically involves theft of funds (premiums). Defamation involves reputation. Coercion involves force.

questions.question: The concept of 'Subrogation' refers to:

options.A: The insurer's right to seek reimbursement from a negligent third party.
options.B: The insured's right to abandon property to the insurer.
options.C: The sharing of risk among multiple insurers.
options.D: The automatic increase of coverage limits.

questions.explanation: Subrogation involves the legal right of an insurer to seek reimbursement from a negligent third party who caused damage to an insured.
questions.distractor_logic: B is Abandonment (which is prohibited). C is Reinsurance or Sharing. D is Inflation Guard.

questions.question: Which of the following causes of loss is explicitly EXCLUDED from coverage under a standard Flood Insurance policy?

options.C: Sewer backup not caused by a general flood

questions.explanation: The policy will not cover damage caused by a broken or stopped up sewer [unless caused by flood]. Covered floods include overflow of tidal waters, mudflow, and surface runoff.
questions.distractor_logic: A, B, and D are part of the definition of a covered Flood.

questions.question: The fiduciary responsibility of a producer primarily involves:

options.A: Evaluating the risk for the underwriter.
options.B: Handling premiums and funds in a trust capacity.
options.C: Drafting the legal language of the policy.

questions.explanation: All producers are required to act in a fiduciary capacity... This means that all producers possess a fiduciary responsibility when engaging in insurance transactions, specifically regarding funds collected.
questions.distractor_logic: A is a field underwriting duty. C and D are insurer responsibilities.

questions.question: In Liability insurance, 'Supplementary Payments' such as defense costs and appeal bond premiums are paid:

options.B: In addition to the policy limits.
options.C: Only if the insured is found liable.

questions.explanation: Such expenses (supplementary payments like legal defense) are paid 'in addition' to the policy's coverage limit or limit of liability.
questions.distractor_logic: They do not reduce the limit (A). They are paid even if the suit is groundless (C). They generally have no deductible (D).

questions.question: Any person who pays a commission to an unlicensed person for selling insurance may be fined:

options.A: Not less than $50 nor more than $500
options.B: Not less than $100 nor more than $1,000

questions.explanation: Anyone violating the regulation against compensating unlicensed persons may be fined not less than $50 nor more than $500.
questions.distractor_logic: $1,000 is for Larceny/Perjury/Unfair practices. $10,000 is for Cease & Desist violation.

questions.question: Under the Massachusetts Personal Auto Policy, Part 2 (PIP) covers medical expenses for all of the following EXCEPT:

options.C: A pedestrian struck by the insured's car in MA
options.D: A motorcyclist struck by the insured's car

questions.explanation: PIP benefits will not be paid for anyone who was operating or occupying a motorcycle. However, the owner of the motorcycle must purchase PIP to protect pedestrians they might strike.
questions.distractor_logic: A, B, and C are all covered persons under Part 2 PIP.

questions.question: Which element of a legal contract ensures that the agreement is not contrary to public policy (e.g., not a contract to rob a bank)?
questions.explanation: A contract must be created with the public interest in mind. Contractual arrangements may not be contrary to public policy (Legal Purpose).
questions.distractor_logic: Agreement is offer/acceptance. Consideration is exchange of value. Competent parties refers to legal capacity (age/mental state).
